  1from typing import TypeAlias
  2
  3import genjax
  4import genjax.typing
  5import jax
  6import jax.numpy as jnp
  7from genjax import ExactDensity
  8from jax.scipy.spatial.transform import Rotation as Rot
  9
 10from b3d.camera import (
 11    camera_from_screen_and_depth,
 12    screen_from_camera,
 13)
 14from b3d.pose.pose_utils import (
 15    uniform_samples_from_disc,
 16)
 17from b3d.types import Array, Float, Matrix
 18from b3d.utils import keysplit
 19
 20inv = jnp.linalg.inv
 21logsumexp = jax.scipy.special.logsumexp
 22logaddexp = jnp.logaddexp
 23CovarianceMatrix: TypeAlias = Matrix
 24PrecisionMatrix: TypeAlias = Matrix
 25RayOrigin: TypeAlias = Array
 26RayDirection: TypeAlias = Array
 27
 28
 29def ellipsoid_embedding(cov: CovarianceMatrix) -> Matrix:
 30    """Returns A with cov = A@A.T"""
 31    sigma, U = jnp.linalg.eigh(cov)
 32    D = jnp.diag(jnp.sqrt(sigma))
 33    return U @ D @ U.T
 34
 35
 36def dq_from_cov(cov: CovarianceMatrix):
 37    sigma, U = jnp.linalg.eigh(cov)
 38    q = Rot.from_matrix(U).as_quat()
 39    return sigma, q
 40
 41
 42def bilinear(x: Array, y: Array, A: Matrix) -> Float:
 43    return x.T @ A @ y
 44
 45
 46def gaussian_restriction_to_ray(
 47    mu_tilde, prec: PrecisionMatrix, o: RayOrigin, v: RayDirection
 48):
 49    """
 50    Restricts a normalized Gaussian to a ray and returns
 51    the mean `mu` and standard deviation `sig`, such that,
 52    parameterizing they ray by $r(t) = o +t*v$, we have
 53    $$
 54        N( r(t) | \\tilde\\mu, cov) = w * N(t | \\mu, \\sigma)
 55    $$
 56    where
 57    $$
 58        w = N( r(\\mu) | \\tilde\\mu, cov) /  N(\\mu, \\mu, \\sigma).
 59    $$
 60    Note that $\\mu$ is the maximum of both the nominator and denominator.
 61    Also note that the first equation implies that the integral of
 62    the Gaussian along the ray is given by $w$.
 63    """
 64    mu1D = bilinear(mu_tilde - o, v, prec) / bilinear(v, v, prec)
 65    sig1D = 1 / jnp.sqrt(bilinear(v, v, prec))
 66    return mu1D, sig1D
 67
 68
 69def cov_from_dq_composition(diag, quat):
 70    """
 71    Covariance matrix from particle representation `(diag, quat)`,
 72    where `diag` is an array of eigenvalues and `quat` is a quaternion
 73    representing the matrix of eigenvectors.
 74    """
 75    U = Rot.from_quat(quat).as_matrix()
 76    C = U @ jnp.diag(diag) @ U.T
 77    return C
 78

 82@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
 83class ProjectiveGaussian(ExactDensity):
 84    def sample(self, key, mu, cov, cam, intr):
 85        """
 86        Samples a 2d pointlight on the sensor canvas from a 3d Gaussian distribution.
 87        """
 88        x = jax.random.multivariate_normal(key, mu, cov)
 89        uv = screen_from_camera(cam.inv().apply(x), intr)
 90        return uv
 91
 92    def logpdf(self, uv, mu, cov, cam, intr):
 93        """
 94        Evaluates the log probability of a 2d pointlight
 95        under a 3d Gaussian distribution.
 96        """
 97        prec = inv(cov)
 98        o = cam.pos
 99        x = cam.apply(camera_from_screen_and_depth(uv, jnp.array(1.0), intr))
100        v = x - o
101
102        # The mode of the restriction of the Gaussian to the ray
103        # from unprojecting the 2d point light at uv.
104        t, sig = gaussian_restriction_to_ray(mu, prec, o, v)
105
106        # The likelihood of the sensor measurement is given by the
107        # integral of the Gaussian along the ray; see the
108        # docstring of `gaussian_restriction_to_ray`.
109        logp = (
110            sig
111            * jnp.sqrt(2 * jnp.pi)
112            * jax.scipy.stats.multivariate_normal.logpdf(o + t * v, mu, cov)
113        )
114
115        return logp
116
117
118projective_gaussian = ProjectiveGaussian()
119
120
121# TODO: Test this code
122@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
123class ProjectiveGaussianMixture(ExactDensity):
124    def sample(self, key, log_weights, mus, covs, cam, intr):
125        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
126        i = jax.random.categorical(keys[0], log_weights)
127        jbinder = (  # noqa: E731
128            lambda j: lambda key, mus, covs, cam, intr: projective_gaussian.sample(
129                key, mus[j], covs[j], cam, intr
130            )
131        )
132        branches = [jbinder(j) for j in jnp.arange(log_weights.shape[0])]
133        x = jax.lax.switch(i, branches, keys[1], mus, covs, cam, intr)
134        return x
135
136    def logpdf(self, x, log_weights, mus, covs, cam, intr):
137        logps = jax.vmap(projective_gaussian.logpdf, (None, 0, 0, None, None))(
138            x, mus, covs, cam, intr
139        )
140        normalized_log_weights = log_weights - logsumexp(log_weights)
141        logp = logsumexp(logps + normalized_log_weights)
142        return logp
143
144
145projective_gaussian_mixture = ProjectiveGaussianMixture()
146

149@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
150class HomogeneousMixture(ExactDensity):
151    dist: genjax.typing.Any
152
153    def sample(self, key, log_weights, comp_args):
154        """
155        Args:
156            `key`: PRNGKey
157            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
158            `comp_args`: Arguments for the components
159                (each row corresponds to a component)
160        """
161        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
162        i = jax.random.categorical(keys[0], log_weights)
163        jbinder = lambda j: lambda: self.dist.sample(keys[1], *comp_args[i])  # noqa: E731
164        branches = [jbinder(j) for j in jnp.arange(log_weights.shape[0])]
165        x = jax.lax.switch(i, branches)
166        return x
167
168    def logpdf(self, x, log_weights, comp_args):
169        """
170        Args:
171            `x`: Sample from mixture
172            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
173            `comp_args`: Arguments for the components
174                (each row corresponds to a component)
175        """
176        logps = jax.vmap(lambda args: self.dist.logpdf(x, *args))(comp_args)
177        normalized_log_weights = log_weights - logsumexp(log_weights)
178        logp = jnp.logsumexp(logps + normalized_log_weights)
179        return logp
180
181
182# TODO: Test this code
183@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
184class TwoComponentMixture(ExactDensity):
185    p0: genjax.typing.Any
186    p1: genjax.typing.Any
187
188    def sample(self, key, log_weights, comp_args):
189        """
190        Args:
191            `key`: PRNGKey
192            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
193            `comp_args`: Tuple of arguments for each components
194        """
195        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
196        i = jax.random.categorical(keys[0], log_weights)
197        x = jax.lax.switch(
198            i,
199            [
200                lambda: self.p0.sample(keys[1], *comp_args[0]),
201                lambda: self.p1.sample(keys[1], *comp_args[1]),
202            ],
203        )
204        return x
205
206    def logpdf(self, x, log_weights, comp_args):
207        """
208        Args:
209            `x`: Sample from mixture
210            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
211            `comp_args`: Tuple of arguments for each components
212        """
213        logp = jnp.logaddexp(
214            log_weights[0] + self.p0.logpdf(x, *comp_args[0]),
215            log_weights[1] + self.p1.logpdf(x, *comp_args[1]),
216        )
217        return logp
218
219
220@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
221class IndexDist(ExactDensity):
222    """
223    Distribution over arrival indices conditioned on being an outlier or not.
224    We mimic a masking combinator here, we don't want to score the arrival index
225    in the case of being an outlier.
226    """
227
228    def sample(self, key, is_outlier, logprobs):
229        i = jax.random.categorical(key, logprobs)
230        return jnp.where(is_outlier, -1, i)
231
232    def logpdf(self, i, is_outlier, logprobs):
233        return jnp.where(is_outlier, 0.0, logprobs[i])
234
235
236index_dist = IndexDist()
237
238
239@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
240class MixtureHack(ExactDensity):
241    def sample(self, key, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
242        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
243        outlier = jax.random.uniform(
244            keys[0],
245            minval=jnp.zeros(2),
246            maxval=jnp.array([intr.width, intr.height], dtype=jnp.float32),
247            shape=(2,),
248        )
249        inlier = projective_gaussian.sample(keys[1], mus[i], covs[i], cam, intr)
250        return jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier, inlier)
251
252    def logpdf(self, uv, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
253        outlier_logp = -jnp.log(intr.width * intr.height)
254        inlier_logp = projective_gaussian.logpdf(uv, mus[i], covs[i], cam, intr)
255        in_bounds = (uv[0] <= intr.width) * (uv[1] <= intr.height)
256
257        return jnp.where(
258            in_bounds, jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier_logp, inlier_logp), -jnp.inf
259        )
260
261
262# TODO: Test this code
263@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
264class MixtureStepHack(ExactDensity):
265    def sample(self, key, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
266        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
267        # Sample from the outlier distribution
268        outlier = jax.random.uniform(
269            keys[0],
270            minval=jnp.zeros(2),
271            maxval=jnp.array([intr.width, intr.height], dtype=jnp.float32),
272            shape=(2,),
273        )
274
275        # Sample from the inlier distribution
276        A = ellipsoid_embedding(covs[i])
277        x = uniform_samples_from_disc(keys[1], 1, d=3)[0]
278        inlier = screen_from_camera(cam.inv().apply(A @ x + mus[i]), intr)
279        return jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier, inlier)
280
281    def logpdf(self, uv, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
282        # The Gaussian parameters
283        cov = covs[i]
284        prec = inv(cov)
285        mu = mus[i]
286
287        # The ray from the camera to the 2d point light
288        o = cam.pos
289        x = cam.apply(camera_from_screen_and_depth(uv, jnp.array(1.0), intr))
290        v = x - o
291
292        # The mode of the restriction of the Gaussian to the ray
293        # from unprojecting the 2d point light at uv.
294        t = bilinear(mu - o, v, prec) / bilinear(v, v, prec)
295
296        # Distance to Gaussian w.r.t. inner product norm
297        dist = jnp.sqrt(bilinear(o + t * v - mu, o + t * v - mu, prec))
298
299        # Volume of the 3-ball and
300        # the length of the intersection of the ray with the 3-ball
301        # TODO: Check if this is correct
302        vol = 4 / 3 * jnp.pi
303        len = 2 * jnp.sqrt(1 - dist**2)
304
305        inlier_logp = jnp.where(dist <= 1.0, jnp.log(len) - jnp.log(vol), -jnp.inf)
306        outlier_logp = -jnp.log(intr.width * intr.height)
307
308        in_bounds = (uv[0] <= intr.width) * (uv[1] <= intr.height)
309
310        return jnp.where(
311            in_bounds, jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier_logp, inlier_logp), -jnp.inf
312        )
313
314
315mixture_step_hack = MixtureStepHack()
316
317
318def add_dummy_var(d: ExactDensity):
319    """
320    Adds a `dummy` variable to a distribution to make it easily mappable while keeping the other args fixed.
321    """
322
323    return genjax.exact_density(
324        lambda key, dummy, *args: d.sample(key, *args),
325        lambda x, dummy, *args: d.logpdf(x, *args),
326    )

@jit
def inv( a: Union[jax.Array, numpy.ndarray, numpy.bool_, numpy.number, bool, int, float, complex]) -> jax.Array: 
 961@jit
 962def inv(a: ArrayLike) -> Array:
 963  """Return the inverse of a square matrix
 964
 965  JAX implementation of :func:`numpy.linalg.inv`.
 966
 967  Args:
 968    a: array of shape ``(..., N, N)`` specifying square array(s) to be inverted.
 969
 970  Returns:
 971    Array of shape ``(..., N, N)`` containing the inverse of the input.
 972
 973  Notes:
 974    In most cases, explicitly computing the inverse of a matrix is ill-advised. For
 975    example, to compute ``x = inv(A) @ b``, it is more performant and numerically
 976    precise to use a direct solve, such as :func:`jax.scipy.linalg.solve`.
 977
 978  See Also:
 979    - :func:`jax.scipy.linalg.inv`: SciPy-style API for matrix inverse
 980    - :func:`jax.numpy.linalg.solve`: direct linear solver
 981
 982  Example:
 983    Compute the inverse of a 3x3 matrix
 984
 985    >>> a = jnp.array([[1., 2., 3.],
 986    ...                [2., 4., 2.],
 987    ...                [3., 2., 1.]])
 988    >>> a_inv = jnp.linalg.inv(a)
 989    >>> a_inv  # doctest: +SKIP
 990    Array([[ 0.        , -0.25      ,  0.5       ],
 991           [-0.25      ,  0.5       , -0.25000003],
 992           [ 0.5       , -0.25      ,  0.        ]], dtype=float32)
 993
 994    Check that multiplying with the inverse gives the identity:
 995
 996    >>> jnp.allclose(a @ a_inv, jnp.eye(3), atol=1E-5)
 997    Array(True, dtype=bool)
 998
 999    Multiply the inverse by a vector ``b``, to find a solution to ``a @ x = b``
1000
1001    >>> b = jnp.array([1., 4., 2.])
1002    >>> a_inv @ b
1003    Array([ 0.  ,  1.25, -0.5 ], dtype=float32)
1004
1005    Note, however, that explicitly computing the inverse in such a case can lead
1006    to poor performance and loss of precision as the size of the problem grows.
1007    Instead, you should use a direct solver like :func:`jax.numpy.linalg.solve`:
1008
1009    >>> jnp.linalg.solve(a, b)
1010     Array([ 0.  ,  1.25, -0.5 ], dtype=float32)
1011  """
1012  check_arraylike("jnp.linalg.inv", a)
1013  arr = jnp.asarray(a)
1014  if arr.ndim < 2 or arr.shape[-1] != arr.shape[-2]:
1015    raise ValueError(
1016      f"Argument to inv must have shape [..., n, n], got {arr.shape}.")
1017  return solve(
1018    arr, lax.broadcast(jnp.eye(arr.shape[-1], dtype=arr.dtype), arr.shape[:-2]))

Return the inverse of a square matrix

JAX implementation of numpy.linalg.inv().

Args: a: array of shape (..., N, N) specifying square array(s) to be inverted.

Returns: Array of shape (..., N, N) containing the inverse of the input.

Notes: In most cases, explicitly computing the inverse of a matrix is ill-advised. For example, to compute x = inv(A) @ b, it is more performant and numerically precise to use a direct solve, such as jax.scipy.linalg.solve().

See Also:

  • jax.scipy.linalg.inv(): SciPy-style API for matrix inverse
  • jax.numpy.linalg.solve(): direct linear solver

Example: Compute the inverse of a 3x3 matrix

>>> a = jnp.array([[1., 2., 3.],
...                [2., 4., 2.],
...                [3., 2., 1.]])
>>> a_inv = jnp.linalg.inv(a)
>>> a_inv  # doctest: +SKIP
Array([[ 0.        , -0.25      ,  0.5       ],
       [-0.25      ,  0.5       , -0.25000003],
       [ 0.5       , -0.25      ,  0.        ]], dtype=float32)

Check that multiplying with the inverse gives the identity:

>>> jnp.allclose(a @ a_inv, jnp.eye(3), atol=1E-5)
Array(True, dtype=bool)

Multiply the inverse by a vector b, to find a solution to a @ x = b

>>> b = jnp.array([1., 4., 2.])
>>> a_inv @ b
Array([ 0.  ,  1.25, -0.5 ], dtype=float32)

Note, however, that explicitly computing the inverse in such a case can lead to poor performance and loss of precision as the size of the problem grows. Instead, you should use a direct solver like jax.numpy.linalg.solve():

>>> jnp.linalg.solve(a, b)
 Array([ 0.  ,  1.25, -0.5 ], dtype=float32)
def logsumexp( a: Union[jax.Array, numpy.ndarray, numpy.bool_, numpy.number, bool, int, float, complex], axis: Union[int, collections.abc.Sequence[int], NoneType] = None, b: Union[jax.Array, numpy.ndarray, numpy.bool_, numpy.number, bool, int, float, complex, NoneType] = None, keepdims: bool = False, return_sign: bool = False, where: Union[jax.Array, numpy.ndarray, numpy.bool_, numpy.number, bool, int, float, complex, NoneType] = None) -> jax.Array | tuple[jax.Array, jax.Array]: 
44def logsumexp(a: ArrayLike, axis: Axis = None, b: ArrayLike | None = None,
45              keepdims: bool = False, return_sign: bool = False, where: ArrayLike | None = None) -> Array | tuple[Array, Array]:
46  r"""Log-sum-exp reduction.
47
48  JAX implementation of :func:`scipy.special.logsumexp`.
49
50  .. math::
51    \mathrm{logsumexp}(a) = \mathrm{log} \sum_j b \cdot \mathrm{exp}(a_{ij})
52
53  where the :math:`j` indices range over one or more dimensions to be reduced.
54
55  Args:
56    a: the input array
57    axis: the axis or axes over which to reduce. May be either ``None``, an
58      int, or a tuple of ints.
59    b: scaling factors for :math:`\mathrm{exp}(a)`. Must be broadcastable to the
60      shape of `a`.
61    keepdims: If ``True``, the axes that are reduced are left in the output as
62      dimensions of size 1.
63    return_sign: If ``True``, the output will be a ``(result, sign)`` pair,
64      where ``sign`` is the sign of the sums and ``result`` contains the
65      logarithms of their absolute values. If ``False`` only ``result`` is
66      returned and it will contain NaN values if the sums are negative.
67    where: Elements to include in the reduction.
68
69  Returns:
70    Either an array ``result`` or a pair of arrays ``(result, sign)``, depending
71    on the value of the ``return_sign`` argument.
72  """
73  if b is not None:
74    a_arr, b_arr = promote_args_inexact("logsumexp", a, b)
75    a_arr = jnp.where(b_arr != 0, a_arr, -jnp.inf)
76  else:
77    a_arr, = promote_args_inexact("logsumexp", a)
78    b_arr = a_arr  # for type checking
79  pos_dims, dims = _reduction_dims(a_arr, axis)
80  amax = jnp.max(a_arr.real, axis=dims, keepdims=keepdims, where=where, initial=-jnp.inf)
81  amax = lax.stop_gradient(lax.select(jnp.isfinite(amax), amax, lax.full_like(amax, 0)))
82  amax_with_dims = amax if keepdims else lax.expand_dims(amax, pos_dims)
83
84  exp_a = lax.exp(lax.sub(a_arr, amax_with_dims.astype(a_arr.dtype)))
85  if b is not None:
86    exp_a = lax.mul(exp_a, b_arr)
87  sumexp = exp_a.sum(axis=dims, keepdims=keepdims, where=where)
88  sign = lax.sign(sumexp)
89  if return_sign or not np.issubdtype(a_arr.dtype, np.complexfloating):
90    sumexp = abs(sumexp)
91  out = lax.add(lax.log(sumexp), amax.astype(sumexp.dtype))
92
93  if return_sign:
94    return (out, sign)
95  if b is not None and not np.issubdtype(out.dtype, np.complexfloating):
96    with jax.debug_nans(False):
97      out = jnp.where(sign < 0, jnp.array(np.nan, dtype=out.dtype), out)
98  return out

Log-sum-exp reduction.

JAX implementation of scipy.special.logsumexp().

$$\mathrm{logsumexp}(a) = \mathrm{log} \sum_j b \cdot \mathrm{exp}(a_{ij})$$

where the \( j \) indices range over one or more dimensions to be reduced.

Args: a: the input array axis: the axis or axes over which to reduce. May be either None, an int, or a tuple of ints. b: scaling factors for \( \mathrm{exp}(a) \). Must be broadcastable to the shape of a. keepdims: If True, the axes that are reduced are left in the output as dimensions of size 1. return_sign: If True, the output will be a (result, sign) pair, where sign is the sign of the sums and result contains the logarithms of their absolute values. If False only result is returned and it will contain NaN values if the sums are negative. where: Elements to include in the reduction.

Returns: Either an array result or a pair of arrays (result, sign), depending on the value of the return_sign argument.

logaddexp = <jax._src.custom_derivatives.custom_jvp object>
CovarianceMatrix: TypeAlias = jax.Array
PrecisionMatrix: TypeAlias = jax.Array
RayOrigin: TypeAlias = jax.Array
RayDirection: TypeAlias = jax.Array
def ellipsoid_embedding(cov: jax.Array) -> jax.Array:

33    D = jnp.diag(jnp.sqrt(sigma))
34    return U @ D @ U.T

def bilinear(x: jax.Array, y: jax.Array, A: jax.Array) -> jax.Array: 
43def bilinear(x: Array, y: Array, A: Matrix) -> Float:
44    return x.T @ A @ y
def gaussian_restriction_to_ray(mu_tilde, prec: jax.Array, o: jax.Array, v: jax.Array): 
47def gaussian_restriction_to_ray(
48    mu_tilde, prec: PrecisionMatrix, o: RayOrigin, v: RayDirection
49):
50    """
51    Restricts a normalized Gaussian to a ray and returns
52    the mean `mu` and standard deviation `sig`, such that,
53    parameterizing they ray by $r(t) = o +t*v$, we have
54    $$
55        N( r(t) | \\tilde\\mu, cov) = w * N(t | \\mu, \\sigma)
56    $$
57    where
58    $$
59        w = N( r(\\mu) | \\tilde\\mu, cov) /  N(\\mu, \\mu, \\sigma).
60    $$
61    Note that $\\mu$ is the maximum of both the nominator and denominator.
62    Also note that the first equation implies that the integral of
63    the Gaussian along the ray is given by $w$.
64    """
65    mu1D = bilinear(mu_tilde - o, v, prec) / bilinear(v, v, prec)
66    sig1D = 1 / jnp.sqrt(bilinear(v, v, prec))
67    return mu1D, sig1D

Restricts a normalized Gaussian to a ray and returns the mean mu and standard deviation sig, such that, parameterizing they ray by $r(t) = o +t*v$, we have $$ N( r(t) | \tilde\mu, cov) = w * N(t | \mu, \sigma) $$ where $$ w = N( r(\mu) | \tilde\mu, cov) / N(\mu, \mu, \sigma). $$ Note that $\mu$ is the maximum of both the nominator and denominator. Also note that the first equation implies that the integral of the Gaussian along the ray is given by $w$.

def cov_from_dq_composition(diag, quat): 
70def cov_from_dq_composition(diag, quat):
71    """
72    Covariance matrix from particle representation `(diag, quat)`,
73    where `diag` is an array of eigenvalues and `quat` is a quaternion
74    representing the matrix of eigenvectors.
75    """
76    U = Rot.from_quat(quat).as_matrix()
77    C = U @ jnp.diag(diag) @ U.T
78    return C

Covariance matrix from particle representation (diag, quat), where diag is an array of eigenvalues and quat is a quaternion representing the matrix of eigenvectors.

@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
class ProjectiveGaussian(genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
 83@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
 84class ProjectiveGaussian(ExactDensity):
 85    def sample(self, key, mu, cov, cam, intr):
 86        """
 87        Samples a 2d pointlight on the sensor canvas from a 3d Gaussian distribution.
 88        """
 89        x = jax.random.multivariate_normal(key, mu, cov)
 90        uv = screen_from_camera(cam.inv().apply(x), intr)
 91        return uv
 92
 93    def logpdf(self, uv, mu, cov, cam, intr):
 94        """
 95        Evaluates the log probability of a 2d pointlight
 96        under a 3d Gaussian distribution.
 97        """
 98        prec = inv(cov)
 99        o = cam.pos
100        x = cam.apply(camera_from_screen_and_depth(uv, jnp.array(1.0), intr))
101        v = x - o
102
103        # The mode of the restriction of the Gaussian to the ray
104        # from unprojecting the 2d point light at uv.
105        t, sig = gaussian_restriction_to_ray(mu, prec, o, v)
106
107        # The likelihood of the sensor measurement is given by the
108        # integral of the Gaussian along the ray; see the
109        # docstring of `gaussian_restriction_to_ray`.
110        logp = (
111            sig
112            * jnp.sqrt(2 * jnp.pi)
113            * jax.scipy.stats.multivariate_normal.logpdf(o + t * v, mu, cov)
114        )
115
116        return logp
ProjectiveGaussian(*args, **kwargs)

404    """Creates a new instance of the class.
405
406    Args:
407      *args: Arguments to __init__.

416    """

419          f"Can't instantiate abstract Struct subclass {cls}. Non-abstract"
420          " subclasses of penzai.Struct must be decorated with"
421          " @penzai.pytree_dataclass before they can be instantiated."
422      )
423
424    return super().__call__(*args, **kwargs)

88        """

91        return uv

projective_gaussian = ProjectiveGaussian()
@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
class ProjectiveGaussianMixture(genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
123@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
124class ProjectiveGaussianMixture(ExactDensity):
125    def sample(self, key, log_weights, mus, covs, cam, intr):
126        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
127        i = jax.random.categorical(keys[0], log_weights)
128        jbinder = (  # noqa: E731
129            lambda j: lambda key, mus, covs, cam, intr: projective_gaussian.sample(
130                key, mus[j], covs[j], cam, intr
131            )
132        )
133        branches = [jbinder(j) for j in jnp.arange(log_weights.shape[0])]
134        x = jax.lax.switch(i, branches, keys[1], mus, covs, cam, intr)
135        return x
136
137    def logpdf(self, x, log_weights, mus, covs, cam, intr):
138        logps = jax.vmap(projective_gaussian.logpdf, (None, 0, 0, None, None))(
139            x, mus, covs, cam, intr
140        )
141        normalized_log_weights = log_weights - logsumexp(log_weights)
142        logp = logsumexp(logps + normalized_log_weights)
143        return logp
ProjectiveGaussianMixture(*args, **kwargs)

@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
class HomogeneousMixture(genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
150@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
151class HomogeneousMixture(ExactDensity):
152    dist: genjax.typing.Any
153
154    def sample(self, key, log_weights, comp_args):
155        """
156        Args:
157            `key`: PRNGKey
158            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
159            `comp_args`: Arguments for the components
160                (each row corresponds to a component)
161        """
162        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
163        i = jax.random.categorical(keys[0], log_weights)
164        jbinder = lambda j: lambda: self.dist.sample(keys[1], *comp_args[i])  # noqa: E731
165        branches = [jbinder(j) for j in jnp.arange(log_weights.shape[0])]
166        x = jax.lax.switch(i, branches)
167        return x
168
169    def logpdf(self, x, log_weights, comp_args):
170        """
171        Args:
172            `x`: Sample from mixture
173            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
174            `comp_args`: Arguments for the components
175                (each row corresponds to a component)
176        """
177        logps = jax.vmap(lambda args: self.dist.logpdf(x, *args))(comp_args)
178        normalized_log_weights = log_weights - logsumexp(log_weights)
179        logp = jnp.logsumexp(logps + normalized_log_weights)
180        return logp
HomogeneousMixture(*args, **kwargs)

@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
class TwoComponentMixture(genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
184@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
185class TwoComponentMixture(ExactDensity):
186    p0: genjax.typing.Any
187    p1: genjax.typing.Any
188
189    def sample(self, key, log_weights, comp_args):
190        """
191        Args:
192            `key`: PRNGKey
193            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
194            `comp_args`: Tuple of arguments for each components
195        """
196        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
197        i = jax.random.categorical(keys[0], log_weights)
198        x = jax.lax.switch(
199            i,
200            [
201                lambda: self.p0.sample(keys[1], *comp_args[0]),
202                lambda: self.p1.sample(keys[1], *comp_args[1]),
203            ],
204        )
205        return x
206
207    def logpdf(self, x, log_weights, comp_args):
208        """
209        Args:
210            `x`: Sample from mixture
211            `log_weights`: Log weights of the components
212            `comp_args`: Tuple of arguments for each components
213        """
214        logp = jnp.logaddexp(
215            log_weights[0] + self.p0.logpdf(x, *comp_args[0]),
216            log_weights[1] + self.p1.logpdf(x, *comp_args[1]),
217        )
218        return logp
TwoComponentMixture(*args, **kwargs)

@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
class IndexDist(genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
221@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
222class IndexDist(ExactDensity):
223    """
224    Distribution over arrival indices conditioned on being an outlier or not.
225    We mimic a masking combinator here, we don't want to score the arrival index
226    in the case of being an outlier.
227    """
228
229    def sample(self, key, is_outlier, logprobs):
230        i = jax.random.categorical(key, logprobs)
231        return jnp.where(is_outlier, -1, i)
232
233    def logpdf(self, i, is_outlier, logprobs):
234        return jnp.where(is_outlier, 0.0, logprobs[i])

Distribution over arrival indices conditioned on being an outlier or not. We mimic a masking combinator here, we don't want to score the arrival index in the case of being an outlier.

index_dist = IndexDist()
@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
class MixtureHack(genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
240@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
241class MixtureHack(ExactDensity):
242    def sample(self, key, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
243        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
244        outlier = jax.random.uniform(
245            keys[0],
246            minval=jnp.zeros(2),
247            maxval=jnp.array([intr.width, intr.height], dtype=jnp.float32),
248            shape=(2,),
249        )
250        inlier = projective_gaussian.sample(keys[1], mus[i], covs[i], cam, intr)
251        return jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier, inlier)
252
253    def logpdf(self, uv, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
254        outlier_logp = -jnp.log(intr.width * intr.height)
255        inlier_logp = projective_gaussian.logpdf(uv, mus[i], covs[i], cam, intr)
256        in_bounds = (uv[0] <= intr.width) * (uv[1] <= intr.height)
257
258        return jnp.where(
259            in_bounds, jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier_logp, inlier_logp), -jnp.inf
260        )
MixtureHack(*args, **kwargs)

422      )
423
424    return super().__call__(*args, **kwargs)

@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
class MixtureStepHack(genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
264@genjax.Pytree.dataclass
265class MixtureStepHack(ExactDensity):
266    def sample(self, key, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
267        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
268        # Sample from the outlier distribution
269        outlier = jax.random.uniform(
270            keys[0],
271            minval=jnp.zeros(2),
272            maxval=jnp.array([intr.width, intr.height], dtype=jnp.float32),
273            shape=(2,),
274        )
275
276        # Sample from the inlier distribution
277        A = ellipsoid_embedding(covs[i])
278        x = uniform_samples_from_disc(keys[1], 1, d=3)[0]
279        inlier = screen_from_camera(cam.inv().apply(A @ x + mus[i]), intr)
280        return jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier, inlier)
281
282    def logpdf(self, uv, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
283        # The Gaussian parameters
284        cov = covs[i]
285        prec = inv(cov)
286        mu = mus[i]
287
288        # The ray from the camera to the 2d point light
289        o = cam.pos
290        x = cam.apply(camera_from_screen_and_depth(uv, jnp.array(1.0), intr))
291        v = x - o
292
293        # The mode of the restriction of the Gaussian to the ray
294        # from unprojecting the 2d point light at uv.
295        t = bilinear(mu - o, v, prec) / bilinear(v, v, prec)
296
297        # Distance to Gaussian w.r.t. inner product norm
298        dist = jnp.sqrt(bilinear(o + t * v - mu, o + t * v - mu, prec))
299
300        # Volume of the 3-ball and
301        # the length of the intersection of the ray with the 3-ball
302        # TODO: Check if this is correct
303        vol = 4 / 3 * jnp.pi
304        len = 2 * jnp.sqrt(1 - dist**2)
305
306        inlier_logp = jnp.where(dist <= 1.0, jnp.log(len) - jnp.log(vol), -jnp.inf)
307        outlier_logp = -jnp.log(intr.width * intr.height)
308
309        in_bounds = (uv[0] <= intr.width) * (uv[1] <= intr.height)
310
311        return jnp.where(
312            in_bounds, jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier_logp, inlier_logp), -jnp.inf
313        )
MixtureStepHack(*args, **kwargs)

408      **kwargs: Keyword arguments to __init__.

412
413    Raises:

415        that it's abstract (or that the user forgot @pytree_dataclass).
416    """

418      raise TypeError(
419          f"Can't instantiate abstract Struct subclass {cls}. Non-abstract"
420          " subclasses of penzai.Struct must be decorated with"
421          " @penzai.pytree_dataclass before they can be instantiated."
422      )
423
424    return super().__call__(*args, **kwargs)

Creates a new instance of the class.

Args: args: Arguments to __init__. *kwargs: Keyword arguments to __init__.

Raises: TypeError: If pytree_dataclass wasn't called on this class, indicating that it's abstract (or that the user forgot @pytree_dataclass).

def sample(self, key, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr): 
266    def sample(self, key, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
267        _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
268        # Sample from the outlier distribution
269        outlier = jax.random.uniform(
270            keys[0],
271            minval=jnp.zeros(2),
272            maxval=jnp.array([intr.width, intr.height], dtype=jnp.float32),
273            shape=(2,),
274        )
275
276        # Sample from the inlier distribution
277        A = ellipsoid_embedding(covs[i])
278        x = uniform_samples_from_disc(keys[1], 1, d=3)[0]
279        inlier = screen_from_camera(cam.inv().apply(A @ x + mus[i]), intr)
280        return jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier, inlier)
def logpdf(self, uv, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr): 
282    def logpdf(self, uv, is_outlier, i, mus, covs, cam, intr):
283        # The Gaussian parameters
284        cov = covs[i]
285        prec = inv(cov)
286        mu = mus[i]
287
288        # The ray from the camera to the 2d point light
289        o = cam.pos
290        x = cam.apply(camera_from_screen_and_depth(uv, jnp.array(1.0), intr))
291        v = x - o
292
293        # The mode of the restriction of the Gaussian to the ray
294        # from unprojecting the 2d point light at uv.
295        t = bilinear(mu - o, v, prec) / bilinear(v, v, prec)
296
297        # Distance to Gaussian w.r.t. inner product norm
298        dist = jnp.sqrt(bilinear(o + t * v - mu, o + t * v - mu, prec))
299
300        # Volume of the 3-ball and
301        # the length of the intersection of the ray with the 3-ball
302        # TODO: Check if this is correct
303        vol = 4 / 3 * jnp.pi
304        len = 2 * jnp.sqrt(1 - dist**2)
305
306        inlier_logp = jnp.where(dist <= 1.0, jnp.log(len) - jnp.log(vol), -jnp.inf)
307        outlier_logp = -jnp.log(intr.width * intr.height)
308
309        in_bounds = (uv[0] <= intr.width) * (uv[1] <= intr.height)
310
311        return jnp.where(
312            in_bounds, jnp.where(is_outlier, outlier_logp, inlier_logp), -jnp.inf
313        )

mixture_step_hack = MixtureStepHack()
def add_dummy_var( d: genjax._src.generative_functions.distributions.distribution.ExactDensity): 
319def add_dummy_var(d: ExactDensity):
320    """
321    Adds a `dummy` variable to a distribution to make it easily mappable while keeping the other args fixed.
322    """
323
324    return genjax.exact_density(
325        lambda key, dummy, *args: d.sample(key, *args),
326        lambda x, dummy, *args: d.logpdf(x, *args),
327    )

Adds a dummy variable to a distribution to make it easily mappable while keeping the other args fixed.
